Black Muslim | Fluent in Spanish, Passable in English | ICD&I Advocate | Fiction writer | Would cook fellow staff on the court
Sep 14, 2016

President Jackson: A Retrospective

A deep dive through a critical lens of Phil’s Knicks decision-making tenure thus far

Phil Jackson joined the New York Knickerbockers in March of 2014 and hasn’t looked back since.

In some cases, not looking back is a good thing, but in the case of the Knicks it strongly reinforces the notion that doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results is the definition of Linsanity.

Everyone remembers the dark times when Isiah Thomas ran the New York Knicks as a coach and as an executive. Saying that Thomas drove the Knicks franchise into the ground for half of a decade is an embarrassingly obvious fact of Knicks history. Thomas’ tenure was riddled with bad trades and arguably, an equally dismal record at 56–108 (via BBall_Ref). That’s a .341 win percentage for the Mathletes out there.

However, this is not about bashing Thomas. This isn’t even about bashing Jackson. This is about unprecedented success in the past being used a proxy for future success in a new role, and why this blind trust has led to Jackson’s power trip.

“In Phil we trust,” was the mantra, and if Phil trusted the Triangle, we swore by it. It was the credo well before “Trust the Process.” The entire Phil Jackson Era is little more than another manifestation of people desperately gripping at nostalgia. While it may seem a bit disrespectful to put Jackson in the same fleeting category as Pokemon Go and Stranger Things, Thomas set the historical precedent as nostalgia gone wrong, and Jackson is just following suit.

Jackson’s first big decision in 2014 was beginning his regime change. From the outside looking in, it appeared more like a hostile takeover. Knicks owner James Dolan was understandably apprehensive in allowing the firings that Jackson was pushing, but the termination of head coach Mike Woodson and his staff could have been seen as an interesting showing of faith by Dolan.

Long before the firing of Woodson just about every NBA stakeholder was certain that the now Los Angeles Clippers assistant coach was on the move anyway. Job security for coaches is very weak, even for proven winners — especially when your team is losing. A new head coach is often one of the early steps when guiding a team in a new direction, but what everyone didn’t know was that the Triangle was more important than the coach running it.

Before he dubbed Derek Fisher the new head coach of the Triangle Offense (or lack thereof), he had his first immediate blunder as an executive, the mishandling of Steve Kerr.

Jackson couldn’t even inspire confidence in Steve Kerr who hopped on the Warriors opportunity after deep talks with Jackson. It was kind of awkward to see the great Phil Jackson with egg on his face and rightfully so; this was the first failure that the world watched Jackson engineer as a Knicks executive. Nonetheless, everyone brushed it off. He had 11 rings and you can take a horse to water, but you can’t make him run the Triangle. Whoever he picked as his legacy would be destined for greatness. Coaching with Jackson in the front office would be like having Warren Buffet whisper trade secrets in your ear.

The Triangle was more important than the coach running it.

He ended up with Derek Fisher. Taking that kind of chance wasn’t exactly what people had in mind, but “In Phil we Trust” calmed everyone’s nerves. The draft would begin soon and then Jackson could really get the ball rolling by utilizing all of the Knicks assets the team had gathered over the years.

Per usual, the Knicks had no draft picks. So, prior to the draft, he quarterbacked a deal where the Knicks gained Jose Calderon, Samuel Dalembert, Shane Larkin, Wayne Ellington, and two second round picks for Tyson Chandler and Raymond Felton. To be fair neither Felton or Chandler were aging well, but don’t the fans deserve a better deal from the Zen Master than what the Knicks got in return? The picks materialized into two shoulder shrugs named Cleanthony Early and Thanasis Antetokounmpo.

Early, the 34th player drafted in the 2014 NBA draft, developed into an irrelevant wing that hasn’t been invited to the Knicks training camp, while Antetkounmpo, the older brother of the Greek Freak Giannis, left for Europe after D-League success did not translate into NBA success. They were two second round picks so, admittedly, expectations were low. And who knew that Jordan Clarkson or Nikola Jokić had that kind of potential early on? Heck, who knew that Jae Crowder would break out like he did? Who knew the Knicks had a chance to acquire his contract? Oh yeah, Phil knew.

And the rest of the players that the Knicks acquired in the deal? They’re all in far worse shape after going through the Madison Square Grinder. Calderon, the ex-starting point guard for the Knicks is happy sitting on the bench for the Los Angeles Lakers. He did not fare well with Knicks fans. His lack of defense and inability to keep healthy were among the greatest grievances against him. Dalembert was released by Dallas before the 2015-2016 season even began. His five points and four rebounds per game average was not missed (and he was arrested for battery). Larkin, who is now playing in Spain, weighed in on his season with the Knicks:

The teams that I’ve been on didn’t have great seasons. When I was with the Knicks two seasons ago, we had a bad year. We didn’t have a good year in Brooklyn either. With the Knicks, there’s no excuses. We tried to adapt to a new system, new coach and new situation for a lot of players and it just wasn’t the right roster for the offense they were trying to run at that particular time. (via HoopsHype)

It appears that unless your one of the greatest shooting guards of all time, Jackson and the triangle doesn’t inspire confidence in young players.

During free agency, Jackson seized the opportunity to take credit for a deal that can only be credited to Carmelo Anthony. History will tell you the Knicks have a habit of overspending, so, the $124 million contract sounds normal if you plan on sticking to the same plan. That deal suggested that the Knicks aren’t moving in a different direction like everyone thought, but just pivoting. This particular pivot was into the worst Knicks season ever. As much as Knicks fans love Anthony, signing an aging superstar doesn’t scream change, it only fill seats, and some people are only satisfied with championships. A young core of promising starters like Al-Farouq Aminu and the then-coveted Lance Stephenson with prospects like Clarkson or Jokić could have led to some interesting defense-focused bully ball that Madison Square Garden was missing. Because if the Knicks are going to lose, most fans would have them lose as they always have, in style.

When the season started, fans were hopeful that the stoic Fisher could perform the same symphonies he did on the court as a maestro on the sideline, ‘Melo had a pep in his step, and everyone was hoping this ragtag group of misfits could come out and show that this major league adaptation had the making of a playoff team.

One season with Fisher and Jackson destroyed the newcomers free agency stock, impeded prospect development, and led to the worst Knicks record ever at 17–65. On the other side of the country Kerr won an NBA championship in his first year as a head coach. It can be argued that rosters played a sizable part, but that doesn’t change the fact that this polar opposite of experiences was a bad look for the Knicks and another failure for Jackson.

As much as Knicks fans love Anthony, signing an aging superstar doesn’t scream change, it only fill seats, and some people are only satisfied with championships.

Finally, Knicks fans and Dolan had something to hope for. No one was sure what Jackson had cooking, but it became clear later that it most definitely was BBQ chicken. Eleven days after an embarrassing lost to the Washington Wizards on Christmas Day the Knicks entered a three-team trade where the Knicks traded shooting guards Iman Shumpert and J.R. Smith for Lou Amundson, Alex Kirk, Lance Thomas and an 8th grader (or a 2019 2nd round pick)

Shumpert and J.R. had their problems, but they were always beloved by Knicks, so, this where are they now? had a bit of a bittersweet ending when it ends with both players being part of the 2016 Cleveland Cavaliers team that overcame a 3–1 deficit to beat the defending Golden State Warriors and unanimous MVP Stephen Curry.

Pressure was mounting for Jackson. The Triangle Offense was failing. These dire straits had to be alleviated and Jackson saw the prime opportunity in the 2015 NBA Draft. The Knicks had to settle for the 4th overall pick, but it was better than nothing.

Jackson became enamored with a mysterious European player who had switched from the previous year’s draft to the current year’s draft. The Knicks hosted private workouts for the then 19-year old big man and Knicks fans were pessimistic to say the least. The huge failure of a year had left a bad taste in everyone’s mouth, even Dolan’s, so, when Jackson pulled the trigger the reaction was less than favorable. Moments later Tim Hardaway Jr. was traded for the 19th overall pick Jerian Grant. There were boos, people laughed, children cried; all-in-all it wasn’t a good time.

Then, this happened.

Kristaps Porzingis, the 4th overall pick, showed people that he could play. He didn’t just shut everyone up, he made believers out of cynical Knicks fans everywhere. Porzingis single-handedly saved Jackson’s career as an executive. However, this deus ex machina did not absolve Jackson of all of his blunders.

The enamoring at Porzingis rookie season would be a much brighter sparkling jewel if all other executive decisions were not clear failures. Grant wasn’t developing partly due to Rambis’ neglect by engineering, Fisher was fired in February, and the Knicks still weren’t winning. The idea of Kurt Rambis leading the team for a full season mortified NYC. Jackson wasn’t going to budge. He was pulling for Rambis since handing him the reigns after Fisher was let go even though his win percentage was .321 for the season.

Jackson held his ground stating:

When Kurt started coaching the team they started executing it with more structure. We saw some progress. But we have to make the next step. (via NY Daily News)

As days went by it appeared that Rambis as the new head coach was becoming more and more likely. Again, Jackson only looked to his intimate circle of friends for a head coach to do his bidding instead of coaching the team himself, the rumor mill suggested.

The number of proven coaches available for hire were plentiful. Appeasing a fan base is not always the best method of management, but when names include Frank Vogel, Tom Thibodeau, Luke Walton, Mark Jackson, and even David Blatt it is not difficult to make a favorable choice. Raving about triangles like a geometry teacher doesn’t attract talent.

Then, in early June, Jackson made a decision, or in better words, Jackson chose to keep his job and he chose to ward off the wrath of angry New Yorkers that was closing in on him as the season ended. The decision wasn’t particularly bold and it wasn’t greeted with high praise or ire, but it wasn’t Rambis. Jeff Hornacek, the ex-coach of the Suns, was selected as the head coach of the Knicks. Hornacek, a former runner-up for coach of the year, explained that he saw the Triangle Offense as a tool for spacing. Jackson even seems a bit more relaxed on the Triangle knowing that a coach with experience will be at the helm. It turns out the hot seat can bring people out of their comfort zone.

The day before the 2016 NBA Draft Jackson decided to shake things up with a trade. Grant, Calderon, and Robin Lopez were traded for Derrick Rose, Justin Holiday and a 2017 2nd round pick. This left-field move excited fans in the moment, but a look down the road left a lot of people scratching their heads.

Calderon’s contract had been less of an annoyance than the playing time he had sucked away from Grant. So, trading a player earning 12 percent of the Knicks cap space for a player who eats up around 28 percent of the cap space is a bit strange when only a year is left on each contract. There is a huge discrepancy in ability when comparing Rose to Calderon, so, the deal makes sense if Jackson has declared that the Knicks are making a run for the title.

The marginally safe hiring of Hornacek and the trade with the Bulls that can easily go wrong seem uncharacteristic of Jackson’s time in New York. However, is there a real baseline that can be used to forecast future decision? Unpredictability can be a useful tool, but when used wildly it looks immature and indecisive. Most of the outcomes from Jackson’s dealings had fizzled into failures or moot.

Until mid-June of 2016 one could easily count the number of impactful decisions that Jackson made on a ninja turtle hand:

  • Drafting Kristaps Porzingis
  • Trading for an ex-MVP with a looming rape case

Separating athletes skills from their actions outside of work is difficult, nearly impossible. This probably means that the two shouldn’t be separated since they do undoubtedly represent the organization that they play for. So, when Jackson took on Rose’s contract he took on Rose’s flaws as well. He chose to have Rose on his team. Regardless of how the civil suit against Rose ends, nothing about what happened is copacetic. In other words, deciding to add Rose to the roster was reckless.

After the four-year $72 million signing of the 31-year old Joakim Noah, the sloppy title run rumor was in full swing. Anthony, Rose, and Noah are three of only five players that finished top five in MVP voting since 2011. All three may be out of the peak of their prime, but this reunion in New York will surely bring the best out of them.

Still, most of the starters have failing bodies. Rose hasn’t played 70 games since his MVP season, Noah’s numbers have taken a turn for the worst since his own injury, and Melo’s left knee won’t last forever. Also, how is Porzingis going to develop? When Rose isn’t taking his own shots, he’ll surely be passing to ‘Melo. Unless Hornacek makes it clear that iso plays a taboo, the sophomore may leave a lot of games with a lot more to give.

However, signing Brandon Jennings to a one year contract is a solid short-term decisions that may yield favorable results. Also, the addition of 3-and-D shooting guard Courtney Lee may be a safer bet than Lance Stephenson.

The Knicks future could have only gotten brighter after a historically awful 2014–2015 season, but is the team really being set up for success in years to come? Does Phil Jackson have a plan in motion that will revive the Knicks franchise to the majesty of yesteryear? With Jackson’s executive leadership, a dynasty with a string of championships like the Lakers, Celtics, or even the Heat’s commendable, 21st century success sounds like a pipe dream.

Making the playoffs is an easier, attainable goal for Jackson to accomplish with this team, the best Knicks team he’s had by far. Bringing winning basketball back to New York might include a 50-win record, but the other part, arguably the most important part, of winning basketball brings accolades much greater than a top seed. It brings banners and confetti. And if Phil’s not bringing what he brought to Chicago and to Los Angeles, then he should have stayed home.

The Knicks want championships.

— Tyler Jordan, site writer

Knicks action starts in two score days (that’s 40 days!). Keep up with developing Knicks news and analysis with The Knicks Wall on our Facebook and Twitter!
